thread.title: People's Vote march: North East campaigners join rally for new Brexit referendum in London

author: Kali Lindsay
title: People's Vote march: North East campaigners join rally for new Brexit referendum in London
text:
Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Get daily updates directly to your inbox Subscribe Thank you for subscribing We have more newsletters Show me See our privacy notice Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email
Scores of anti- Brexit campaigners from the North East headed to London to join thousands of people at a rally calling for a new referendum.
Coaches from the region set off to the capital for the People's Vote march, with some of the coaches being sponsored by celebrities, including David Miliband.
Organisers say more than 500,000 took part in the march that started at Park Lane and ended in a rally at Parliament Square.
NE4EU (North East 4 Europe), which is campaigning to keep strong links with the EU, arranged for campaigners from Tyne and Wear to attend the event. Anti-Brexit campaigners take part in the People's Vote March for the Future in London, a march and rally in support of a second EU referendum. (Image: PA)
Spokeswoman Christina Mueller-Stewart said: "As each day goes by, the prospect of Theresa May avoiding Britain crashing out of the EU in a chaotic no deal Brexit grows ever more stark, with massive implications for the North East's economy and citizens. Read More No-deal Brexit would do 'lasting damage' to North East, business leader says
"The people are marching to send a powerful message to politicians that we have no confidence in their ability to protect the national interest and that a People's Vote is the solution to the Brexit chaos they have created."
The group held a rally in Sunderland earlier this month and said there is a growing realistion on Wearside that Brexit is turning out to be a bad deal.
Celebrity cook Delia Smith, Dragons' Den businesswoman Deborah Meaden and London Mayor Sadiq Khan were among the speakers at Saturday's rally in London.
The People's Vote campaign said its stewards estimated the size of the crowd to be around 570,000.
Speaking ahead of his appearance, Mr Khan said the rally would be a historic moment in our democracy. Mayor of London Sadiq Khan takes part in the People's Vote March for the Future in London, a march and rally in support of a second EU referendum. (Image: PA)
He added: "A moment when in their thousands, people from every corner of our country and every section of our society will take to the streets - coming to make our voice heard.
"We've heard some complain that a public vote would be undemocratic and unpatriotic. But the opposite is true. There's nothing more democratic - nothing more British - than trusting the people to have the final say on our future."
The lies, the mistruths and the deceptions of the referendum campaign have now been exposed, and it's clear the will of the people is changing, he added. Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now
"No one voted to leave the EU to make themselves poorer. No one voted to make life harder for our children and grandchildren," he said.
"No one voted to see our NHS damaged. And no one voted for the shambles that this Government has created." Read More Lib Dem leader Vince Cable urges Theresa May to break Brexit deadlock by backing a 'People's Vote'
Delia Smith said people were not fully informed when they voted but now understood "the dire consequences".
"The only way we can avoid this total madness and win back our future has to be a People's Vote," she said.
In a video message of support, Nicola Sturgeon, the First Minister of Scotland, said: "Let me say this loudly and clearly, if the issue comes before the House of Commons, SNP MPs will support a People's Vote which includes the option to remain in the EU."
Mrs May has ruled out another referendum saying the People's Vote has already been held and that was the initial vote. Like us on Facebook
